subject: Not for the Little Old Lady from Dubuque...
event:
... was how THE NEW YORKER was once pitched, when it was launched way back when.

(I actually lived in Dubuque from 1976 to 1979.  I think half the population of the town read THE NEW YORKER, just to prove they were more sophisticated than those New Yorkers thought).

Which is a long and roundabout way of saying, hey, there's a profile of me in the latest issue of THE NEW YORKER.

No April Fool here.  Really truly.

How cool is that?

comments.article:
I remember that, from the movie Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle.

Congratulations!

comments.upictitle: Names Is For Tombstones, Baby: Rocketeer
comments.article: You won't really have made it until you (and your half-frog Atlantean lovechild) are featured in the Weekly World News.  Or at very least, the National Inquirer.
comments.subject: Congratulations, but...

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: spider
comments.article: Indeed. And then the New York Times will run a trend piece about him and we'll know that It's All Played Out. ;-)
comments.subject: Re: Congratulations, but...

comments.article: Hey, I'm a subscriber and I live in a small town. We're very near a large city, though. Next stop: Cover of the Rolling Stone!
Then what? GRRM joins Aerosmith on tour?
I'll have to buy and read my first copy of The New Yorker
comments.subject: That's Wonderful

comments.article:
Yeah, it's cool to be in The New Yorker, but ... but ...

Have you read it?
Congratulations :) But to really know you, we've got to read those books. Roll on July!
BWAH-HA-HA! Quite frankly, as a Little Old Lady from Dubuque, I never had much time for the New Yorker, but I do read all of your books and that is what is important, right? ;-D

No, seriously, I hope you do "do a LOST." And that's a compliment, not a slight.

You said "do a LOST" as if it was a bad thing, because you didn't like the ending. Now, it's fine if you didn't like the ending, but damning it as bad because you didn't like it, that's where I have to call you out.

Here's the rub - regardless of whether you liked or disliked the ending of LOST, the writers seemed rather pleased with it, because they believed that they had told the story to their specifications. More important than delivering answers to a show that, from the outset, couldn't have all of them, they decided to be true to the *story* instead. They wrote the ending of LOST to be the ending of LOST, not the fan version where we understand the why of everything.

What's troubling is that you seem to indicate that you *don't* want to do this. Please, please, please, don't be tempted to write characters or plot lines to fit what *we* want, because, honestly, we're a bunch of unwashed Neanderthals that won't be pleased under any circumstances. We'll want to know why X happened or demand that you wrote Y character wrong or Z should have lived or whatnot. You're never going to please all of us. Every single one of us is going to have a gripe, even if we love it from first word to last.

So don't try to please us. And when we whine and mewl and pitch a fit and tell the New Yorker that we don't want our next endeavor to "pull a Martin," you can look back and say "To hell with 'em, I wrote the story that needed to be written."

It's *your* story, just like it was the LOST writing team's story. You do with it what you want. You write it how it needs to be written. The only person you really need to satisfy is yourself, and by extension, the story itself. I think by this point, you've earned enough of a following to do as you please with it.

Just like the LOST staff did.

So please, do a LOST. Write the story that needs to be written the way you want to write it. Because, for the record, I loved the ending of LOST.
comments.subject: Do a LOST?

comments.article: This is the first time that I ever created an account on a website I like to follow just to reply to one single post: pbagosy, you are so right!
comments.subject: Re: Do a LOST?

comments.article:
You're blowing up George.

The rest of the world is about to find out what the rest of us have known for years -- that you're the best fiction author of this generation.
comments.subject: Face it

comments.article:
Good to see you enjoying your success...you deserve it.

I can imagine that right now is your reward for the last 10 years of struggle...knowing that you had something entertaining to share, but also being pushed and pulled by what you write as if it has a mind of its own. Plus the stress and strain of trying to comply with publisher's who want you to star in their traveling circus to every flea port on the planet.

[Raises a toast (with butter and jelly)] To you Ser, and a full life to come.

Oh, you New Yorker! The entirety of the article is for subscribers only. What do they think, that people ought to pay money to receive goods or services? That's so 20th century!

...off I go to buy a copy over lunch...

However, good for them for calling out the apostates, as they call them, who seem to believe that they're owed the next books in the series when they want them:

"An entire community of apostates—a shadow fandom—is now devoted to taunting Martin, his associates, and readers who insist that he has been hard at work on the series and has the right to take as much time as he needs. The online attacks on Martin suggest that some readers have a new idea about what an author owes them. They see themselves as customers, not devotees, and they expect prompt, consistent service."

...so much as profiled them. Mr. Martin will be the first to tell you that he's messed up in his PR/estimations of completion along the way.

I have been reading since 1996 and I can tell you that I understand where they're coming from, even if I don't agree with their methods. The debate about whether or not readers are owed a conclusion is not as crazy as some here would like to make it seem.

I'll explain before everyone throws eggs at me: Serials (which is what ASoIaF is) are sold with the explicit understanding that there will be a conclusion at some point. I think that is why Mr. Martin is feeling so much pressure to get it right, and why this process has been so incredibly tough for him.

Personally, I am glad he cares so much and am really pulling for him to finish a book that he's happy with. These detractors simply don't believe that he's been frank with them, that there is some great conspiracy on George's part to deprive them of what they feel they deserve. Mr. Martin's relative silence about Dance these past couple of years only served to reinforce these fears.

So I get it. I mean, if anything it is a testament to Mr. Martin;s sheer skill as a story teller that people are getting so riled up. I like the emotion, if not the execution.

I must say, Elio's devotion is bordering on OCD to hear the author tell it. Glad he's doing it, for all of our sakes, but man, that's dedication.
comments.subject: I don't know if the author called them out...

comments.article:
Wired wrote a nice article about why people should see HBO's GoT series.

http://www.wired.com/geekdad/2011/04/10-reasons-why-you-should-watch-game-of-thrones/

I hope this link works.
comments.subject: You're also in Wired Mr. GRRM

comments.article:
A few years ago, while vacationing in Miami, I was shocked to discover some books set in what I thought was the GURPS Supers universe that my friend Felipe(GameMaster extraordinaire) had once described to me in detail. Growing up in Chile, you'll excuse me if my access to pop culture was a bit more limited in the pre-wikipedia times. Then I bought the first Wild Cards anthology and got the story straight. I was actually drawn to "A Song of Ice and Fire" (partly) because of Wild Cards, and not the other way round.

Now I found out that this pilot I caught on cable way back when, that I still want to see more of, about that weird chick from another dimension, and the hero doctor, the fuel eating bacteria and the guy that I can only asume was going to get killed in every episode, was also written by you.

I think was 13 at the time, so I might be over indulgent, but my memories of it are quite positive. Please tell me: was Spiderman one of the faces carved on that alternate Mt. Rushmore or is that just my memory tricking me? I have a fuzzy recollection of that. I really wanted to know what was up with THAT reallity.

Anyway, I think it is so cool the way you're discreetly yet firmly woven into geek pop culture, and to recognize that subtle presence you've had in my life for so long, from Vincent to JetBoy to Tyrion. I just wanted to say you Rock, sir, and thanks for all the stories.
comments.subject: DOORWAYS!

comments.upictitle: He wasn't looking for a five minute thrill: Default / Itsa Me!
comments.article: Apparently Damon Lindelof was hurt that you disliked the end of Lost and took his case to Twitter (in a friendly manner). Any chance of you responding, boss? :)

George, are you aware that Damon Lindelof has challenged you to a nerd fight over comments you made about Lost to The New Yorker?

https://twitter.com/DamonLindelof#
comments.subject: Damon Lindelof

comments.article: Congratulations, I can tell you're really loving it all.
The story is great! FWIW, the fact that you've written four of my favorite books and a dozen of my favorite short stories makes me want to give you a hug, not bitch about you on my blog.
I'm suprised at the content of this article. Actually some insight into your fandom divide there. Crazy.
comments.subject: Wow...

comments.article:
Congrats! And it's a nice article (and also the quotation from Gaimon is great). Though I was pretty horrified to read about the vitriol that's coming out of people who feel entitled to more work (by you, not by them, apparently)... had no idea :(
Anyway, thank you for sharing your words and works!

You stirred up a little controversy with that article. First, Damon Lindelof declares a feud (http://twitter.com/damonlindelof). Then, Digital Spy mentions your expectations of fan disappointment (http://www.digitalspy.com/ustv/news/a312860/game-of-thrones-author-expects-upset-fans.html). All this attention has gotta be fun.

I look forward to talking about the LOST finale with you at SDCC

Namaste!

ps. There WILL be a turd left on your doorstep
comments.subject: turds on doorsteps

comments.article:
It's thanks to this article that we have a war with the guy from Lost.

Call Banners!
That means when you share a negative opinion about something another celebrity has created, you're gonna hear about it. That must be weird...
comments.subject: You're an A-Lister now!

comments.upictitle: The great, the knowledgable, the one, the only...: pic#111100213
comments.article: You know you've made it big when you're being featured in the magazine founded on being holier-than-thou and raising the bar on bourgeois humor (Excelsior!). As an Author, so far as it goes, it's a pretty big accomplishment to add to the ol' resume.
